Es Casada, tiene 64 años y es madre D. 03 hijos, todos ellos ya independientes.El espíritu luchador que siempre le ha caracterizado y las ganas D. salir adelante con sus propios medios le ha valido para iniciar su propio negocio D. venta D. anticuchos en las fueras D. su casa donD. poco a poco fue haciéndose muy conocida entre sus clientes y hoy nos cuenta que le va muy bien en este tipo D. actividad.  Sus ventas lo realiza  diariamente  a partir D. las 6:00pm. Tiene años trabajando en este negocio y se siente muy contenta con lo que hace. Con este préstamo D. S/ 3,000.00, comprará insumos como arroz en sacos, huevos, gallinas criollas para sus juanes y pollos desviscerados para sus anticuchos, asimismo utensilios D. cocina para brindar un servicio D. calidad.  Josefa, se siente muy tranquila y contenta con lo que hace  y  agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento D. sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Josefa is a member of the "Virgen D. la Inmaculada" Community Bank, in the District of Tarapoto, San Martin Province, city of San Martin. She is 64 years old and is married with 3 children, all of whom are independent. She has a fighting spirit which has always defined her and has enabled her to move forward in life. Josefa began her own business by selling "skewers" outsiD. of her home, where she gradually became very well known among her customers and is how she works each day until 6pm. She tells us that her business is going very well and she is pleased with her accomplishments. With this loan, she intends to purchase bagged rice, eggs, creolle hens and pre-cut chicken pieces, as well as some cooking utensils/ serving utensils for her business. Josefa feels very much at peace and is content with what she does for a living, and thanks the Manuela Ramos Organization for their help towards the fulfillment of her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprará insumos, para prepar sus comidas. (to purchase necessary ingredients for her catering service)

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita T. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 60 years old and is married. To make a living, Clarita owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling dried coconut meat ("copras") in the local community. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Clarita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Clarita is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Clarita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao Y. E. is 51 years old, married and the mother of four children, two of whom are married. Her husband, Pum Vuthy, 55 years old, is a radio-telephone repairman.

Mao sells costume jewelry in the local market, earning around $8 each day. Her business is running smoothly and is profitable because she is particularly able to attract customers. 

To better satisfy her customers’ desires, Mao would like a loan from Kiva through Hattha Kaksekar Limited, a partner of Save the Children. With her loan she would acquire more costume jewelry to sell. Note: Mao Y. E. was busy at her business so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To acquire more costume jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo B. is from the municipality of Guinsiliban within the province of Camiguin, Mindanao. He is 45 years old, married and has four school-aged children. Alfredo owns and operates a motorcycle taxi (or habal-habal) in which he transports local community members. Alfredo is also a fisherman.

In 2009, Alfredo joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Alfredo is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. He has already repaid a second loan used for the same purpose of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. He plans to use all additional revenue to improve his business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Leng S. is 31 years of age and married to a military policeman. They have been married for years and have three children; one is married, while the other two are single and garment workers.

Leng operates a little grocery store in front of her home. She has been in business for eight years and is earning approximately $4 per day. As the rice fields come to maturity, Leng S. is looking for capital in order to buy rice in bulk at a reasonable cost from farmers so she can resell it when it commands a better price.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk directly from the rice farmers.

loans.name: Raineria

texts.en:
Raineria P. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 50 years old, and is separated from her spouse. To make a living, Raineria works in the food sector making and selling barbecue products to the local community. (Her business is also known as "alacart.") Raineria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Raineria is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Raineria from HSPFI.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Chim

texts.en: Chim S. is 29 years old, married, and a mother. She is a local rice cultivator, and has been doing this since 1999. She has three children, all three of whom attend school and are dependent on her income. On the other hand, Chim also takes time to fish with her husband along Tunle Sap River, earning $3 per day. Chim will use her loan to buy bamboo to make other fishing tools, which she and her husband use to fish.

loans.use: To buy bamboo to make fishing tools.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel A. is 30 years old and has three children. Her husband is Mr. Artemio A. and they happily live in a village located at Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. All of their children are studying in the secondary and elementary levels of education. Because of their interest to give their children a better future, they are striving hard to support their schooling.

They cultivate their farm lot twice a year by planting vegetables and root crops. Aside from this, Maribel also buys and sells vegetables to help her husband in gaining  more income. She sells her products at Solano Public Market during market days, as well as in their village through house to house delivery. Since her capital is not sufficient to acquire more vegetables, she wants to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders of Php10,000 to increase her capital and improve her small business. She expects that with this financial assistance, she will be able to improve her business and earn more income for the sake of their children.

loans.use: For additional capital to buy and sell vegetables.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios is 48 years old and she is married to Agustin, a Brgy. Captain in their village. They are blessed with six children, three of whom are already married and three are still studying. Remedios hopes that her children will finish their education some day.
 
Remedios is engaged in raising hogs in their village. As a business woman, she also wants to increase her income by increasing the number of hogs she raises. She hopes to borrow an additional loan for her to buy more hogs. She is requesting a loan of PHP4,000 for additional capital. She will also use the loan to purchase a supply of feed to sustain the proper growth of her hogs.
 
To obtain additional income for her family, Remedios also picks corn crops on the farm. She earns a profit of PHP100 daily from this work, which is being used for the educational needs of her children.

loans.use: To purchase additional hogs and feed.

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva P. lives, together with her family, in the village of San Isidro, Ilagan, Isabela. She is married and blessed with one child who is presently studying. She dreams of providing for all of her child's needs and sending her to college someday with the help of her business.  

Minerva is engaged in selling furniture using her brochures. She has been in business for four years, and according to her, it has improved with the help of her previous loans. She is requesting a loan of Php4,000 to help her business further grow. She will use it as additional capital for her furniture retailing business. She is expecting more income with the help of the loan she requested. She hopes that it will be approved to be able to purchase more simple furniture to retail.

loans.use: To purchase more furniture to sell.

loans.name: Mary Joy

texts.en:
Mary Joy A. is from the village of Casinglot, Tagoloan Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old and with one school-aged child. To make a living, Mary Joy owns operates a business selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Mary Joy has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Mary Joy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mary Joy is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is taking care of her pig at the back of her house. She gives it pig feed, and she hopes that she will have sufficient capital to buy more feed. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP to help her acquire a supply of feed for her pig. She hopes that someday she can buy more pigs to raise in order to earn more income in the future. She hopes that Kiva lenders will assist in the growth of her business. 

Leonora is a 45-year-old businesswoman. She is married and has five children, and most of them are currently studying. She is really doing her best to make her business progressive.

loans.use: To buy a supply of feed for her pig.

loans.name: Susette

texts.en:
Susette V. is from the village of Usocan. She is 27 years old, is married, and has two infant children.

Susette owns and operates a business providing motorcycle and other motor vehicle equipment repair services to local community members. Her business is by the roadside and she provides assistance to those whose vehicles break down while driving, as well as typical repair to anyone who brings their equipment to her. Susette has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Susette joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital.

Susette is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy, 37 years of age, is a walking vendor in the village of Magdalena, Cabatuan, Isabela. She works in the selling of fish. Her weekly net income approximates $5 daily. Her desire to acquire more income motivated her to request the loan amount of 5,000 PHP to purchase more fish in the public market and sell in her village.

Nancy is married and they are blessed with four children who are in high school and elementary levels of education. She struggles to work hard for the daily necessities of her children, to supplement the family's income, to improve her business and to have a productive life.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Chhoem

texts.en: P. was born in 1968. His wife's name is Hean Somchan, and she is 42 years old. They live together in Kampong Chhnang Province. P. currently earns a living by working as a district soldier. His wife sells smoked fish that she either buys from a supplier or makes herself. This old couple has three school-aged as well as employed kids. P. always finds it hard commuting to work because he has no vehicle for riding. He is requesting a loan to add to his little savings to buy a used motorbike to provide his transportation to his workplace.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike for transportation

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
“Try your best until you succeed!” says Mrs. Janet L. of Barangay Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the loving housewife of Mr. Marcelino L., and they are blessed with two children, Joemar L. and Gay L.. Through their patience and sacrifices, they finished a vocational course and applied it in their own business.

Her husband cultivates their farm lot. During planting season he plants a variety of vegetables and rice. Janet is engaged in buying and selling vegetables in their village. She aims to acquire more vegetables to be sold at Solano Public Market, but she does not have enough capital.

Therefore, she wants to borrow 15,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to strengthen her capital in acquiring the said vegetables. She hopes that with this financial assistance, she can improve her small business to earn a living and save for their future.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda would like to borrow a loan amounting to 5,000 Philippine pesos to pursue her livestock business. She plans to purchase hogs to raise for an additional source of income. Aside from hog raising, she is involved in a retail business. She sells ice candies, fruits, cooked snacks, juice and small toys in front of the school campus near their house. Most of her customers are elementary and a high school students, that’s why she sells a lot of her products. She hopes to further expand her business by having additional items to sell. She also hopes to have a hog-raising business with the help of the loan she requested.

Imelda is 53 years old. She is from the village of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isbaela. She is already widowed and still supporting two out of her four children. Her two other children are already married while the two she supports are still staying with her in her house. She also dreams to have a more comfortable life with the help of her business. She hopes that Kiva lenders could help her in reaching her dreams.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase hogs to raise

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah T., 44, is a workaholic. She puts in a lot of time attending to her many businesses.  She lives in the heart of Dasmariñas, Cavite.
 
Sarah has been managing her general store for 10 years. In her spare time, she attends to her direct-selling business. She also embarked on selling electronic load credits for mobile phones – a hit additional source of income among Filipinos. All combined, she makes 15,000 Philippine pesos a month.
 
She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2008. She needs a new loan in the amount of P11,000 to purchase more cosmetic items and basic items for her general store. She also wants to purchase a bicycle she can use for daily transportation.

Sarah says she wants to see her family all together again, a dream she has grown up with. She now works hard to be able to expand her businesses. 

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social-development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Grocery items and bicycle for transportation

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan N. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 23 years old. Joan is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Joan runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Joan has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joan is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Joan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Judit

texts.en:
Judit A. is from the village of Purok Piape, Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Judit owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Judit has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Judit joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Judit is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
This is Alma Q., a 39-year-old vendor from Caloocan City. She lives with her three children, one of whom is in high school and another of whom is in grade school. Her husband, Alberto, has a business buying and selling.

Alma has been tending her hamburger stand for seven years now. She also sells fresh eggs. She is earning more than 16,000 PHP a month. Much of her profits go to meet her children’s educational needs. Alma is thankful to Kiva partner, the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. The loans it provides help her pursue her business. She is now on her ninth loan cycle with her application for a new loan of 8,000 PHP for use as additional capital.

About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: As additional capital

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor V. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 55 years old, married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Victor owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling bananas in the local community. Victor has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Victor joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Victor is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Through the hardships and difficulties of life, Jenelyn D. and her husband, Rogelio, of Barangay Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya, are striving to earn a living to satisfy their basic needs and support the schooling of their two children. They want their children to be successful in their chosen professions so that they have a bright future and do not experience what their parents have experienced.

Farming is the couple's main source of income. They till their parcel of land during the planting season by planting rice and some vegetables. Jenelyn is engaged in the buying and selling of vegetables. She acquires her products from farmers and sells them at Solano Public Market and also in their village. Her monthly income is just enough to meet their basic needs. Therefore, Jenelyn wants to borrow additional capital amounting to 15,000 PHP to acquire more vegetables to sell. She hopes that the loan will be of great help in strengthening her small business.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo B. is commonly called “Ilyong” in his village located in Barangay Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. Danilo is a widow with six children. Despite this, he has a strong determination to give his children a better future. He works hard to earn a living for their survival and save for their future. Most of his children are already married and manage their own families.

The common source of Danilo's income is farming, and he plants rice and vegetables twice in a year. Furthermore, he is also engaged in hog raising to earn some additional income. He aims to increase his crop production and improve his piggery but he does not have enough capital. Therefore, he wants to borrow 5,000 PHP to purchase agricultural supplies to achieve these objectives. He believes that he will be successful in his plans through this financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural supplies to increase crop production and improve his piggery

loans.name: Sheilah Veb

texts.en:
Sheilah Veb E. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 27 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Sheilah Veb owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Sheilah Veb has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Sheilah Veb joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Having the desire to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Arlene N. and her husband are striving hard to earn more income to support the schooling of their children. They live harmoniously in the village of Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya.

Farming is the livelihood of her husband. He cultivates their farm by planting rice and vegetables. Arlene engages in selling fish and frozen foods in their village to help her husband in gaining income. Being a responsible mother, she can earn a net income of $110 a month, which she uses to acquire their basic needs and to finance the schooling of their children.

She wants to acquire more fish and frozen foods, but her capital is not enough; therefore, she applied for loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 9,000 PHP to further develop her business. She hopes that lenders will grant her requested loan.

loans.use: To buy more fish and frozen foods to sell.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna and her husband help each other to earn a living for the sake of their children's future. They work really hard to finance the education of their beloved children because they want them to be employed and become successful. They endure hardship and difficulties, hoping that their efforts will bear good fruit.

Lorna's husband cultivates their farm twice a year by planting rice and vegetables, while Lorna is engaged in hog raising to help her husband earn extra income. They want to improve their piggery and increase their crop production, therefore Lorna wants to borrow 15,000 PHP to acquire agricultural supplies to achieve these objectives. They believe that their business will be successful through their patience and hard work.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural supplies to increase crop production and improve piggery

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
This is Zenaida J. of Tala, Caloocan City. She is 45 years old. Her husband Gerry, 48, is a carpenter. They have five children, one each in college, high school and grade school. The rest stay at home.

Zenaida is into a variety of business. She gets herself into anything that is in demand at the moment. But she indulges herself and makes more money on rag making. She buys scrap fabrics from neighboring garment factories and tediously sews each small piece to become round rags.

Zenaida said she feels like just playing with the fabric. She has been in this industry for more than a year now. She earns 18000 PHP a month.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative only last year but is already impressed at how the cooperative takes care of its members. She has just finished repaying her 3rd loan with CCT. On her 4th cycle, she has applied for 10000 PHP to purchase more colorful fabric trimmings from the nearby factories.

Someday, she hopes to see her life literally improve from “rags to riches”.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more scrap fabric trimmings for rag making.

loans.name: Net

texts.en:
Mr. Net E. is a villager in Roka village in Kandal province. He owns a truck that he uses to transport garment factory workers to work for an income. In this business, he now faces a problem because his truck needs to be fixed so he decided to ask for a loan to repair his truck.

Mr. Net E.’s wife, Mrs. Seourn Tida, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. They have five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. His wife is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To repair his truck

loans.name: Mrs. Thoeurn Pok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of twelve people, is located in Prey Kokir village in Takeo province. Mrs. Thoeurn P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Thoeurn P. is a farmer who owns 0.7-hectare (1.75-acre) field on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Aside from this plantation, she also raises pigs.

Since her pig business is doing well, Mrs. Thoeurn P. wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and pig feed. She will use the rest of the loan to buy chickens to raise, too. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s standard of living.

Mrs. Thoeurn P. is the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are studying in the local school. Her husband, Mr. Tuy Rom, is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, pig feed and chickens to raise

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida A. is now 51 years old and already a widow. Her husband met with an accident and unfortunately died. At that time their child was only two years old.

Despite of what happened, Leonida was not discouraged because she thought of their child’s future, and taught their child. Through her patience and sacrifices, her daughter graduated with a degree of Bachelor of Science in Elementary Education. She presently teaches at Baresbes Elementary school.

For the sake of their future, Leonida continues her business to help her daughter in earning income for their survival and for their future.

Leonida engages in buying and selling of charcoal. She also plants some vegetables in the garden which she sells at Solano Public Market. She plans to buy more charcoal and plant more vegetables in their garden for her to earn more income.

In this regard she is requesting 9000 PHP from KIVA lenders for additional capital.

loans.use: Additional capital for selling vegetables and charcoal.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena F., 45, has been in the general store business for seven years, and opened her own store three years ago. She lives in Malaria, Caloocan City with her husband Gerardo, who works as an office clerk, and their two children.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative three years ago, at the same time she established her general store.  The loans provided to her by the cooperative helped her increase her inventory making her store attractive to her neighbors.  She now earns more than P14,000.00 a month and sees an even larger income in anticipation of the yuletide season.

Now on her tenth loan cycle, she applied for a new loan in the amount P18, 000.00 as additional capital. She hopes to convert her small store to a full-pledged grocery outlet.

texts.en: Mrs. Khkaing Nat is group leader of seven people who all live in Trapeang Tuem village in Takeo province. Mrs. Khkaing Nat is a vegetable seller in the local market. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to re-sell. She hopes to increase the living conditions of her family. Her husband, Mr. Seng Thy, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Khkaing Nat has four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the youngest is too young to work or study because this child is three years old.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio B. lives in Barangay Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 49 years old and is married to Emily B.. They are blessed with two children. Being a responsible father, both of their children have finished their degrees and are now working abroad.

The common source of their living is farming. They help each other to cultivate their farm by planting rice and vegetables. Since harvesting takes a long time, Rogelio engages in the buying and selling of charcoal and vegetables from their village. The products are then sold at Solano Public Market through retailing. He can able to earn a net income of PHP3,000 a month, which he uses to acquire their daily basic needs and is able to save some income for the families' future. Since his business is profitable, he wants to continue it and acquire more products but his capital is not sufficient. He plans to borrow from KIVA lenders an amount of PHP9,000 to further develop his capital and income.

loans.use: additional capital in buying and selling of charcoal

loans.name: Sat's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sat U. is a group leader of four people who lives in Pou Preah Sang village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sat U. is a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. KU. Huyny, is a farmer who owns 0.9 hectares to cultivate rice. This couple does not have any children yet.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Jenie

texts.en:
Jenie C. is from the village of Bobontugan. She is 33 years old, is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Jenie owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of vegetable products in the local community. Jenie has been in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jenie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jenie is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase more vegetables to expand product offerings. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jenie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables  to expand product offering

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Due to hardships and difficulties of life, Josephine and Melesio A. help each other earn a living for their survival and to give their daughter a better future. They live in a village of Barangay Buliwao, Quezon,Nueva Vizcaya.	

Their main source of income is through farming. They plant rice and vegetables twice a year. Sfter planting her husband uses their tricycle to earn income while Josephine engages in selling the vegetables in their village and at the public market. The average income she earns for the month is about to 3,000 PHP which they use to acquire their daily needs and for their daughter's school. She is able to earn additional income if she sells more vegetables. Since her capital is not sufficient, she wants to borrow a 5,000 PHP loan from KIVA lenders which will be used in acquiring more fruits and vegetables to resell. She hopes that she will become successful in her journey as a businesswoman.

loans.use: additional capital in buying and selling of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita C. is 68 years old and is a very happy mother because she is able to achieve her dreams for her family, especially her children. Nenita lives in Prk Masinadyahon and is married to a pensioner, Victor C.. They have six children who are grown and have their own families, with a total of 19 grandchildren. In spite of her age, she continues her business because this is the bread and butter of her family.  

Her husband used to work as a carpenter in a milling company with an income that was not enough to compensate for household expenses. She engaged herself in different types of businesses like fish vending, farm work, selling of native delicacies from other barangays and would do laundry for their neighbor to help her husband with expenses. At the wee hours of the morning, Nenita would start her daily routine of taking care of her children while preparing for her businesses. In 1999, she became a member of NWTF-PD and her loan was used for her general store which was adjacent to her house. She also sold different viands to her husband's company. With this additional income for her family, she was able to send her children to school. Luckily, her business did well and she was able to earn PHP 9,000 that month, which was used for savings and to defray some family expenses.

Nenita continues to loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 was used as an additional capital for her general store.  She paid for this particular loan on time without any delay. Borrowing the same amount of PHP 15,000, she will be buying additional working inventory for her general store and the income from it will be used for family improvements and other investments.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional working inventory for general store

loans.name: Foisaga

texts.en:
Foisaga F. is a 33-year-old woman living in the town of Gagaifo Lefaga. She is married and has one infant child.

Foisaga owns and operates a business planting and harvesting taro for sale. She has been engaged in this business for years and earns approximately 1,500 WST a month from these activities.

Foisaga joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Foisaga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,700 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase harvesting equipment.

Foisaga is now requesting a new loan of 2,400 WST which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. The loan will be her 4th from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Mrs. Toeurn Loch Village Bank Group

texts.en: Nineteen people who are all living in Ta Soeng village in TaK. province make up the village bank loan. Mrs. Toeurn L. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members, and they all will use their loans for different purposes. Mrs. Toeurn L. is a farmer who own a 1-hectare field to cultivate rice. Aside from this farming, she is a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets for breeding to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Khat Sarith, is a construction worker who can make a small income to support the family.  Mrs. Toeurn L. is 26 years old and the mother of three children who are all too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding to earn more income.

loans.name: Bot

texts.en: Mrs. Bot K. is a villager in Chan Teab village in Takeo province. She has a two-hectare field to cultivate rice to earn a living. She is also a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Chheong Boeurn, is a construction worker who can make a small income to support the family. Mrs. Bot K. is 30 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because this child one year old. Mr. Chheong Boeurn is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To to buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is a 47-year-old entrepreneur from Novaliches, Quezon City. She lives with her husband Emiliano, 47, a cable guy, and their three children.

She owns and manages a computer shop catering to internet surfers, gamers and mostly students.  She has been in this business for five years.  Elizabeth makes about $650 a month.  She enjoys dealing with customers of all ages and from different walks of life.  Customer traffic peaks in the afternoon after classes and on weekends, she says.  

Elizabeth is now on her sixth loan cycle since joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  She has been enjoying many benefits from being a member.  She is currently in need of funds to restore and update some of her computer units for the convenience of her clients.  She applied for a 8,000 PHP loan with CCT to address this need.
 
She hopes to open another computer shop branch in another area. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Upgrade of computers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en: Mrs. Lorn B. is a villager in Chan Teab village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. She is also a pig breeder. Since the pig-breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding and pig food. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living situation with this loan. Mrs. Lorn B. is a widow with two children who are both employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding and pig food.

loans.name: Tống Thị's Group

texts.en:
"C. Tống Thị (10117050033) is a 55-year-old female living in the town of Đông Anh - Hà nội.  C. is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Đản Mỗ 1 (1).


C. is married and has two adult children.  To make a living, C. operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  The main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale.  C. has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately $112 a month from these activities.


In 2003, C. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  C. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5.300.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5.886.000 VND which will be used in the same way.  This will be her sixth loan from SEDA.  C. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Tống Thị M. (10117050032) is a 48-year-old female who is requesting a 2.834.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Nguyễn Thị H. (10117050034) is a 35-year-old female who is requesting a 1.962.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide micro-finance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


C. Tống Thị (10117050033) là 55 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông Anh - Hà nội.  C. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Đản Mỗ 1 (1).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  C. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 8 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, C. kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND.  Vào 2003, C. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  C. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.300.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.886.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Tống Thị M. (10117050032) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 2.834.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Nguyễn Thị H. (10117050034) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 1.962.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Phy

texts.en: Mrs. Phy U. is a villager in Trapeang Phlu village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sam Khon, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Phy U. has five children, two of whom are working in a garment factory while two others drive motorbikes with a cart to transport passengers and goods for an income. The youngest one is attending the local school. Although they try to work hard, they do not earn enough income to support the family, and they do not have any money to buy a new cart for their children's business. The cart is too old. To deal with this problem, Mrs. Phy U. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new cart for her children's transportation business. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more grocery products to resell to earn more income. She hopes to improve her business and provide a better life for her children. Her husband, Mr. K. Chan, is a farmer. Mrs. Sokhorn K. has one child who is working as a laborer in Thailand. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

Mrs. Nhorn M. is a villager in Thkov village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living.

Mrs. Nhorn M. is a widow with one child who is a construction worker. Since his workplace is far from home, Mrs. Nhorn M. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her child to drive to work. This will reduce expenses.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mr. Saroeun L. is a villager in Thkov village in Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Sek Theara, are farmers who own a small piece of land on which they cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, they also raise pigs.

Since this pig business is going well, they want to expend it. Thus, Mr. Saroeun L. decided to ask for a loan to purchase four more piglets to raise. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family’s standard of living with this loan.

Mr. Saroeun L. is the father of five children, three of whom are attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. His wife is on the right in the photo.

loans.name: Vat

Mrs. Vat T. lives in Prambei Mom village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Touch Proeun, is a recyclables collector who collects empty bottles, cans and so on to resell for an income. Although they try to work hard, they still earn insufficient income to support their family and better their standard of living. 

Now Mrs. Vat T. is applying a loan to buy a cow for breeding. This couple has four children; two are employed in a garment factory while the other two are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.name: Korb

Mr. Korb E. lives in Krang Sbaek Village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who has a small piece of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Keov Yeourn, sells cake in the local village. Although they try to work hard, they still earn insufficient income to support the family.

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
This is Eliza D. R., a 53-year-old general store owner who lives in Tala, Caloocan City, with her husband Mariano, a driver, and their four children.

Eliza opened her store three years ago and has since been an alternative source of income for her family.  It is located just in front of their house.  She earns more than $225 a month.  She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative only last year but has since been active in inviting other women in her community to her group.  She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative.  Now on her 4th loan cycle, she has applied for a fresh loan in the amount of 10,000 PHP as additional capital for her store. She dreams of having a larger grocery store someday.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Mrs. Net H. lives in Troey Troeng village in Kandal province. She is a chicken breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to request a loan to buy more chickens for her business. Her husband, Mr. Huy Senglon, helps her with the business.

loans.name: Circle Cambodia Sewing Cooperative Group

texts.en:
Five single women in their early 20's recently formed a new sewing cooperative called Circle Cambodia, creating a new chapter in life and a fresh start. These women work together and live together in Phnom Penh, and their bond of friendship runs deep,  as they have overcome incredibe adversity together. 

All of these women come from difficult family backgrounds, namely large single parent families. One of the women was orphaned at an early age and another suffered from abuse. With the assistance of a counter-human trafficking NGO, the women left their families in the rural provinces and moved to Phnom Penh to attend vocational training school. This NGO provides alternative livelihood options for children deemed to be at high risk of trafficking due to vulnerable family situations. Once sewing school was complete, the five women of Circle Cambodia found employment with a woman who ran a small tailor shop out of her home. This woman did provide housing, but unfortunately she made some poor financial decisions and became heavily indebted, and within a short time she started withholding salaries from her employees, using the money to pay down her own debt instead. Without having another place to live, the women of Circle Cambodia were trapped in an exploitative working and living situation. One year later a tailor shop customer found out about the injustice of the working conditions, and she facilitated a way out for the women, provided them with a new place to live and a promise of future business once the women were able to buy their own sewing machines.  

Phany, one of the youngest women in the group, has the most sewing experience. She has been sewing since 2003 and is an accomplished seamstress. She excels at cutting patterns - a skill she is teaching the other group members who started sewing in 2007.  Phany's cheerful personality, friendly demeanor and quite confidence seems to be a unifying force in the group. Phany grew up in Kompong Cham province of Cambodia. Her father died when she was young, which resulted in great financial hardship for the family as Phany's mother tried to support her 10 children. Prior to coming to Phnom Penh, Phany was working in the fields, picking beans, for a wage of $0.75 a day. Phany enjoys sewing, and her outlook on the future of Circle Cambodia is bright. 

Each member of the Circle Cambodia co-operative requested a loan of $145 to be used for the purchase of a sewing machine. The disbursal meeting was filled with excitement, and the women already had plans for an afternoon trip to the market to shop for machines. Circle Cambodia has secured initial orders and they look forward to expanding their business to include Cambodian customers and possibly even foreign customers through an online global marketplace. The women take English lessons for one hour each day, and the women are teaching an illiterate member of the group how to read in the Khmer language. The Circle Cambodia co-operative  dreams that one day their business will be successful enough for them to start training new employees who come from similar vulnerable backgrounds. 

About SIGU:
This loan is the first made by AMK's Special Interest Group Unit (SIGU). As part of the Product Development department, SIGU was developed as an initiative to further reflect AMK’s mission, and to serve more ‘vulnerable’ groups that are currently underserved by microfinance services. These groups include women who are victims of trafficking, domestic violence and other gender-based traumas, people living with HIV/AIDS, street people and children and people with disabilities. AMK is currently focusing on assisting women who are victims of trafficking, domestic violence and other gender-based traumas. Current SIGU projects include developing microfinance specific financial literacy training and creating a pilot credit program specific to this population.

loans.use: buy sewing machines.

loans.name: Jomelyn

texts.en:
Jomelyn L. is also called as “Melyn” in their village. She is now 34 years old and has three children. They live happily in the village of Barangay Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. They aim to improve their status of living so that they can give their children a better future. They work hard and sacrifice their time to earn a living for their survival and for the schooling of their children.

Melyn's husband is a security guard in Solano High School while Melyn is engaged in selling vegetables in their village and also at Solano Public Market. She uses their tricycle to deliver their vegetables to the market. Through her patience and sacrifices, she can able to earn a net income of PHP 4,500 a month which they use to meet their daily needs and finance the schooling of their children. She wants a loan of PHP 5,000 to acquire more fruits and vegetables. She is happy because through the loan she can make her business more progressive.

loans.use: Buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Nisar Ahmad

texts.en:
This is Nisar Ahmad son of Z. K.. He lives in Jalalabad city in district 3 Th. He is 32 years old, married, and has two wives. He owns a spare-parts shop. He sells spare parts and also does repairs. Through the income from his business he supports his family.

When Nisar Ahmad was informed about the loan process that is supporting the people, he came to AFS and requested a loan of 50,000 Afghani to buy essential materials and to expand his business.

Nisar Ahmad hopes to progress his business after taking the loan. He looks for new changes in his business and he is sure that he will repay his loan on time and will request his second loan after he has soon completed repaying his first one.

Nisar Ahmad would like to thank both Ariana Financial Services (AFS) and Kiva lenders who support people around the world.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts

loans.name: Illumenada

texts.en:
Illumenada P. is from the village of Bobontugan, Jasaan Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Illumenada is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Illumenada owns a sari-sari (variety) retail store with video games, and sells a variety of products in the local community. Illumenada has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Illumenada joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and give her the ability to engage in business. Illumenada is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Illumenada from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena C. is a 39-year-old general store owner who has also been in the canteen business for ten years. She lives with her three children among the poor communities in Camarin, Caloocan City.

Rowena loves to cook and serve food to her neighbors along with tending the general store, which gives her an income of more than PHP 14,000 a month. She hires an assistant from the neighborhood to help her tend to customers, especially on busy days.

She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for four years now. Rowena is already on her 8th loan cycle. She needs a loan in the amount of PHP 17,000 to sustain her store and food business.

She dreams of having her own restaurant someday. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Grocery items and recipe ingredients

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn T. is now 34 years old and she has four children. She is married to Larry T. and they live peacefully in the village of Brgy. Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. Having great ambition to their children makes them to work hard to earn a living and finance the schooling of their children.

The major source of their living is through farming.They till their land twice a year, planting rice and vegetables. Furthermore, Marilyn engages in buying and selling vegetables and fruits in their village. She sells her products at Solano Public Market during market days and also to their village through house-to-house delivery. She uses her income to meet their daily needs and to finance the tuition fees of their children. She wants to acquire and sell more fruits and vegetables but she cannot purchase more due to lack of capital. Therefore, she wants to borrow PHP 6,000 to be added in her capital to acquire more products to sell.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more  fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Mia

texts.en:
Mia L. is from the town of Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 29 years old. Mia is separated from her spouse. To make a living, Mia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Mia has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Mia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and give her the ability to engage in business activities. Mia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Mia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Mercilita

texts.en:
Mercilita L. is from the village of Bobontugan, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. Mercilita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Mercilita runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Mercilita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mercilita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercilita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her store's product offering. This will be the first loan taken out by Mercilita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Mary Anne

texts.en:
“If you want to succeed, always think positive!” That is an inspiring quotation shared by Mrs. Mary Anne B. of Barangay Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Ric B. and they are blessed with two children. They help each other to earn a living for their survival and for the future of their children.

Mary Anne's husband is a carpenter in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya, while she helps her husband in gaining income by selling MSE and Natasha cosmetics products in their village. She wants to acquire more of these products so she can sell more to their village but she cannot afford to due to lack of capital. Having the interest to continue her business, she wants to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders amounting to 5,000 Philippine pesos to acquire more of these products. She is so happy with this financial assistance that gives her the opportunity to continue and improve her small business.

loans.use: Additional capital for selling costmetics

loans.name: Benedicto's Group

texts.en:
Benedicto M. is a 62-year-old, hardworking man. He is married with 11 children, three of whom are still in school as he also takes care of three grandchildren and one orphan. Benedicto has had multiple businesses -- poultry, bricklaying and the sale of produce -- in Kitega for 29 years. His major business challenges are the changes in prices depending on the season. He is able to make about 200,000 Ugandan shillings in profits a week and that helps him in taking care of his family and saving for future developments. His dream is to spread his business to other areas apart from his village as well as to build rental houses for monthly earnings.

Benedicto needs a loan to help buy more feed for his chicken as well as more produce for resale, since loans have boosted his businesses.

loans.use: Buying more chicken feed and more produce for resale

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is 55 years old. She has been engaged in fish selling in their village. Her daily net income is PHP 250. She desires a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 from KIVA lenders for additional capital for her business. She plans to purchase some fish to sell in their village to be able to gain more profit.

She is married and blessed with seven children. Some of them are already married and some are still single and have jobs. She is living with her husband at the village of Magdalena, Cabatuan, Isabela. According to her, when trials come, she endures them patiently.

loans.use: Additional capital in her fish vending business

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is 49 and married with three children aged between 24 and 27 years. None of her children goes to school, but her grandchildren do go to school. She owns a four-roomed house where she is staying with six people. Deborah takes care of additional family members.The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She uses public transport to and from shopping. Deborah works seven days a week and receives an average of 25 customers a day. She sells to all categories of people but at retail only. Her major business challenges include the ever-increasing prices of second-hand clothes and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her because she works in an open place. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and medication. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for ten years, servicing her twentieth loan. Deborah joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with it. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and start selling at wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Amilita

texts.en:
Amilita P. is from the village of Bobontugan, Jasaan Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Amilita is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Amilita owns a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Amilita has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Amilita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and give her the ability to engage in business activities. Amilita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Amilita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nymph

texts.en:
Nymph C. is from the village of Mahinog Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old. Nymph is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Nymph owns a specialized retail store, selling longganisa and chorizo sausages, and ready-to-wear Items in the local community. Nymph has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Nymph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and give her the ability to engage in business activities. Nymph has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Nymph is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Nymph from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
