Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao S. is 30 years of age and a resident of Kampong Chhnang Province.

Mao currently works growing rice on the farm and has been doing this work since 1997. She now has two school-aged children, both of whom also work on the farm when they are not learning.

Mao is applying for a Kiva loan to buy bamboos, which she will weave as nets and traps for her husband’s fishing business.

loans.use: To buy bamboos to weave as nets and traps.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta S. is from the village of Calabayan, Ozamiz City. She is 35 years old, married, and has five school-aged children.

Violeta is a food vendor and has been engaged in this business for six years, earning approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

On January 12, 2009, Violeta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC.

Violeta is now requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP as additional capital for her business. This will be her 3rd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to support the financial needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional meat and ingredients

location.town: Calabayan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental, Mindan

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en: Laxmi F. is from the village of Olingan. She is 59 years old, is married, and has six adult children. Laxmi owns and operates a business providing transportation services such as motor cab to the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In the photo, Laxmi is shown with her husband who operates the motor cab. In 2006, Laxmi joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital for her existing sari-sari (variety) store. Laxmi is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in her business. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Ablawa Jeannette

texts.fr: E. Ablawa Jeannette est née en 1949 et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Ablawa Jeannette a deux autres enfants en charge, en plus de ses enfants. C'est une veuve vivant au quartier Gbégamey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis 42 ans. Ablawa Jeannette supporte toute seule les charges de sa famille. Ablawa Jeannette n'a jamais été à l'école. Cela fait 5 ans déjà que Ablawa Jeannette mène comme activité la vente de "Sodabi" (boisson alcoolisée locale) à son domicile et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Ablawa Jeannette vend également de maïs et de farine de manioc. C'est à Adja et à Dogbo, deux villages du Bénin que Ablawa Jeannette s'approvisionne. Ablawa Jeannette a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Ablawa Jeannette souhaite augmenter son fonds de roulement et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C'est pourquoi, Ablawa Jeannette sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
E. Ablawa Jeannette was born in 1949 and is the mother of four children who are all in school. She has two other children to support in addition to her own. She is a widow and has been living in the Gbégamey district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for 42 years. Ablawa Jeannette is the sole support for her family. She has never been to school. For five years already, she has been running a business selling sodabi (a local alcoholic drink) out of her home and at Dantokpa, the international marketplace of Benin. She also sells corn and cassava flour. Adja and Dogbo, two villages in Benin, are where she stocks up. Ablawa Jeannette has had two ALIDé loans before and has repaid them. She wishes to increase her working capital and to satisfy her customers further. This is why she’s requesting another ALIDé loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy containers of a local alcoholic beverage

loans.name: Dative

texts.en:
Dative is 37 years old and is married with four children aged between 1 and 9 years. She lives in the Rwamagana district approximately one hour and half drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. It is in this area where she has owned a shop selling foodstuffs since 2005, working from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Dative realized that her profit is still too low to expand meaningfully and she believes that a small amount of additional capital would change that for her. For that reason she is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to purchase some additional foodstuffs. This will enable her to attract new customers and increase her sales and (hopefully) profits as well.

With the continued success of her business, Dative will be able to continue paying school fees for her children and will be able to build a secure future for them.

loans.use: To purchase some additional foodstuffs

loans.name: Soem

texts.en:
Soem S., 53, currently resides with five children in a small home located in Kampong Chhnang Province.

She works as a cleaner in the busy market and her husband works as a construction worker. The couple can generate an income of at least $4 a day to contribute toward their family’s daily living expenses.

Soem hopes to earn extra income by using a Kiva loan for capital to purchase rice in bulk to sell and gain more profit.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Marcializa

texts.en:
Marcializa A. is from the village of Looc, Catatarman, Camiguin. She is 32 years old. Marcializa is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marcializa owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. Marcializa also runs a sari-sari (variety) store.

In 2009, Marcializa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcializa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Marcializa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marcializa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: C2255 Ubumwe Group

texts.en:
Sylivestre is 37 years old and is married with three children. He lives in Kabuga where he is the president of a group called “Ubumwe”. This is the fourth successful year in their business of selling small fish commonly known as “indagara”. The group works from 6 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day.

The group is requesting its first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through purchasing a greater volume of indagara fish. With this loan, the group hopes to get better pricing for their product and improve their business and hopefully earn more profit in the process. This, in turn, will allow the members and their devoted spouses to build a secure future for themselves.

loans.use: To purchase a greater volume of indagara fish

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena M. is from the village of Canibungan Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has seven school-aged children. Elena owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2005, Elena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elena is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: C2879 Ubuwe Muyombo Group

texts.en:
Evelyne is 26 years old, married with 2 children aged 6 and 10 years old. Evelyne has been a proven entrepreneur for many years, and now she is the president of a group called “UBUMWE MUYOMBO” This is the tenth successful year of this group in selling animals like sheep and cows. This group runs their business from 6 AM to 3 PM every day.

This is the first time for this group to request the loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. When they are lent this money, they hope that it will allow them to buy more domestic animals for sale as well as increasing a number of their customers and hopefully making more profits. With this profit Evelyne is saving for buying a house that she and her spouse have long dreamed of owning.  Also, it will allow them to continue paying school fees and provide more and better food for their families.

loans.use: obtaining more animals for sale

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros R. is from the village of Tinaclaan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old. Milagros is single. To make a living, Milagros owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Milagros joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Milagros from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her income.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia D. is from the town of Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 53 years old. Nelia is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Nelia owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. Nelia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Nelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to start a new business. Nelia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Nelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Saom

texts.en: Saom T. is a 38 year old woman and the mother of three children. One of her children is employed in the garment industry. She and her husband currently weave bamboo baskets for sale. They operate the basket business after they finish planting and harvesting their rice crop. The family makes many sets of baskets before selling them. T. sells her finished produce to her nearby neighbors, who then take it to sell at the market. T. is requesting a loan to purchase more raw materials for weaving baskets.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials for weaving baskets.

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: A. Awa est née en 1980 et vit depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Gbégamey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une célibataire ayant à sa charge trois enfants, dont deux sont ses propres enfants et qui sont tous scolarisés. Awa n'a pas évolué dans les études et n'a fait que le cours primaire. Awa vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Il y a trois ans déjà que Awa mène comme activité, la vente d'igname et également d'igname pilé (nourriture locale communément appelée "Agoun") dans sa boutique à Aïbatin, un quartier de Cotonou. Awa fait ses approvisionnements à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et agrandir plus sa clientèle, Awa sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Awa was born in 1980 and has been living for 12 years in the Gbégamey district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is unmarried and has three children to support. Two of them are hers, and they are all in school. Awa didn’t advance in school and only completed her primarly education. She lives alone with her children and is the sole support for the family. For three years already, Awa has been running a business selling yams and also pounded yams (a local food commonly called agoun) in her shop in Aïbatin, a district of Cotonou. She supplies herself at Dantokpa, the international marketplace of Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans. To increase her working capital and to expand her customer base more, she’s requesting a third ALIDé loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of yams

loans.name: Alowia

texts.en:
Alowia A. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste ice cream and is requesting a loan to purchase more groundnuts to make more paste to sell. Alowia is 32 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house and provide food at home.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase more groundnuts to make more paste to sell.

loans.name: C2554 Twungubumwe 2 Group

texts.en:
Beatha is 35 years old, married with 2 children, aged 3 and 7 years. Beatha operates the business of selling foodstuffs at Kabuga, which is just under an hour's drive from Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.  A proven entrepreneur, she has been the president of a group called “TWUNGUBUMWE 2” since 2001. The hours of their business require that they work from 8 AM to 10 PM every day.

This group is requesting its first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through purchasing some additional foodstuffs that are in demand like potatoes and groundnuts. With this additional business, this group hopes that their life will change progressively as they can make more money through their efforts, continue to pay school fees for their children, and set aside some savings for their futures.

loans.use: A VARIETY OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

loans.name: Myraflor

texts.en:
Myraflor T. is from the village of Zone 4, Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 22 years old. Myraflor is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Myraflor owns and operates a business venture running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling alacarte (grilled meat) pork products in the local community. Myraflor has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Myraflor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myraflor is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Myraflor from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: C2867 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Marie Claire is 30 years old, married with 4 children. Marie Claire operates a business selling foodstuffs at Kabuga where she has been the president of a group called “ABISHYIZEHAMWE” since 2003.  The hours of their business require that they work from 6 AM to 7 PM every day.

This group is requesting their first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses through purchasing more foodstuffs for sale. Through this expansion, they hope to attract many customers as well as increasing their profit. With this profit, this group hopes that their lives will change progressively as they can make more money through their efforts, continue to pay school fees for their children, and set aside some savings for their futures.

loans.use: More agriculural products for sale

loans.name: C2880 Amizero Group

texts.en:
Jeanne is 36 years old, married with 3 children. Jeanne has been a proven entrepreneur for many years and now she is the president of a group called “AMIZERO” This is the second successful year of this group which works in the decoration business. Work starts at 6 AM and lasts until 6 PM every day for AMIZERO.

This group is requesting its first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their decoration business, which they hope will attract many customers as well as making dditional profit. This profit will allow them and their devoted spouses to buy a house they have long dreamed of owning; it will also allow them to continue paying school fees and provide more and better food for their families and build a secure future for them.

loans.use: Decoration items

loans.name: Genereuse

texts.en:
Genereuse is 44 years old, married with 2 children aged 12 and 14 years old. She lives in Gicumbi district approximately one hour's drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Genereuse is a new entrepreneur owning a restaurant only since last year. Her busy restaurant is open early in the morning till late in the evening every day.

Genereuse is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy some new kitchen equipment and food to cook. In addition, she will be able to paint the walls of her restaurant so that it will look smart and attract more customers. Through accessing this loan, if her expansion plans are successful, Genereuse will be able to continue her life as a self-employed woman with a successful enterprise. The savings from additional profits that are not reinvested in her business will allow her to take even better care of her 2 children.

loans.use: MORE VARIETY OF FOODSTUFFS

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Pech T., 37, is a military policeman. To help with the family’s daily expenses, his wife sells fresh fish in the local market. Pech is a good father with a young child.

Pech T. finds it hard to get to work because he doesn’t have his own vehicle. He is therefore applying for a loan to purchase a used motorbike which he will use to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 48 years old, married with 3 children aged 11,15, and 20 years old. Jacqueline lives in the Gicumbi district approximately a one hour's drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Jacqueline is an experienced entrepreneur, owning a shop selling a variety of clothing styles since 2006. The hours of her business require that she work from 7 AM to 5 PM every day.

Jacqueline is seeking a small amount of additional capital to allow her to expand her business. For that reason, she is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to purchase a greater variety of attractive clothes so that she may attract many customers as well as increase her sales and profits. If this business is successful, Jacqueline will be able to continue paying school fees and provide more food for her children. In addition she will be able to build a secure future for them.

loans.use: A GREATER VARIETY OF CLOTHES TO SELL

loans.name: Elivanie's Group

texts.en:
Elivanie is 30 years old, married with 4 children with ages between 5 and 12 years old. Elivanie lives in the Gicumbi district which is approximately one hour drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.  Since 2007, Elivanie has owned a shop selling some household items as her photo indicates I mean Household items such as Margarine, Sugar,Thermos, Radio, Handbags.


Elivanie is requesting her first loan from Kiva Lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her shop through purchasing more items such as thermos, radio, Handbags and some other needed household items for sale, which, she hopes,will attract more customers as well as increase her sales and profits.  As she builds her business, Elivanie will continue to provide more and better food for her children and build a secure future for them.

loans.use: Household items such asMargarine, Sugar,Thermos, Radio, Handbags,....

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie E. is from Barangay Tumpagon, a village within Cagayan de Oro City on Mindanao. She is 35 years old, married and has five school-aged children. Rosie runs her own sari-sari (variety) store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. Rosie has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Rosie joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Rosie is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP, her fourth from HSPFI (her third, successfully repaid, was a loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI). She will use her loan to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use all revenue from her business to supplement her family’s income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell in her "sari-sari."

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Rakhat's Group

texts.ru:
Койчукеева Рахат – лидер данной группы. Рахат обратилась за кредитом с целью купить лошадь и на оставшуюся часть кредита закупить овец для дальнейшего разведения. Рахат вот уже двадцать четыре года занимается животноводством. Помимо этого, она торгует мясом и продаёт молоко. Своё хозяйство Рахат начала очень рано. Сразу же после свадьбы родители Рахат подарили ей тридцать голов овец. Рахат приложила всё своё усердие и старание, чтобы увеличить семейное достояние и сумела увеличить поголовье до ста голов. Вместе с мужем они купили дом в г. Кара – Балта. Муж также сумел выкупить небольшую территорию лесного хозяйства. Её муж работает лесником. Сейчас Рахат сорок восемь лет. Она вместе со своим мужем вырастила четверых детей. Сейчас старшей дочери Рахат уже двадцать два года. Её уже выдали замуж и теперь она живёт со своим мужем. Остальные дочери живут с родителями. Ежемесячный доход Рахат составляет около двенадцати тысяч сомов. Этого вполне хватает для содержания семьи. Однако Рахат не хочет останавливаться на достигнутом. Теперь её планы на будущее включают в себя покупку автомобиля, а также приобретение квартиры в г. Бишкек. 

В группу Рахат также входят Карыпбаева Гульнара, Орозобекова Бурул и Осмонкапарова Айнаш. 

Карыпбаевой Гулнаре сорок семь. У Гульнары трое детей. Старшая дочь живёт отдельно. Двое сыновей живут вместе с Гульнарой. Гульнара вдова. Гульнара, привыкла чувствовать постоянную поддержку, и опору со стороны мужа, стойко выдержала тяжкое испытание, выпавшее на её долю. Дети подросли и вполне могли бы позволить Гульнаре не работать и сидеть дома. Однако, она успешно работает охранником в магазине. Гульнара решила приобрести корову. Из – за отсутствия нужной суммы она и обратилась за кредитом.

Орозобековой Бурул пятьдесят один. Бурул вдова. Она решила получить кредит, чтобы закупить шапок и носков. Раньше она торговала очками. Теперь Бурул решила попробовать продавать что-нибудь другое. Для своих детей Бурул была и остаётся замечательным примером самостоятельности. Все её шестеро детей уже давно выросли и сами себя обеспечивают. Однако Бурул предпочитает иметь собственное дело. К тому же её месячный доход составляет около десяти тысяч сомов. 

Айнаш сорок шесть. У неё четверо детей. Муж Айнаш вместе с ней дома занимается хозяйством. Они разводят овец и продают молоко. Айнаш решила обратиться за кредитом, для того, чтобы купить дойную корову.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Rakhat K. is this group’s leader. Rakhat has applied for a loan in order to buy a horse and, with the rest of the money, to buy sheep for breeding. Rakhat has been working in animal husbandry for twenty-four years. Additionally, she sells meat and milk. Rakhat’s business started very early. After her wedding, her parents gave her thirty head of sheep. Rakhat has put all of her effort and diligence into increasing the family’s holdings, and has managed to increase the number of livestock to one hundred head. She and her husband bought a house in Kara-Balta. Her husband also has managed to buy a small piece of forest. Her husband works as a forester. Now Rakhat is forty-eight years old. She and her husband have raised four children. Now Rakhat’s oldest daughter is twenty-two years old. She is already married and lives with her husband. The other daughters live with their parents. Monthly, Rakhat’s income is about twelve thousand som. It is enough to support the family. However Rakhat does not wish to stop now. Now her future plans include buying a car and getting an apartment in Bishkek. Rakhat’s group includes Gulnara K., Burul O., and Aynash O.. Gulnara K. is forty-seven. Gulnara has three children. Her oldest daughter lives separately. Her two sons live with Gulnara. Gulnara is a widow. Gulnara, who used to get constant support from her husband, bravely survived the ordeal which has befallen her. Her children have grown up, and they could allow Gulnara to stay home and not work. However, she successfully works as a security guard in a shop. Gulnara has decided to get a cow. Because she lacks sufficient funds, she has applied for a loan. Burul O. is fifty-one. Burul is a widow. She has decided to take out a loan to buy caps and socks. Earlier she sold glasses. Now Burul has decided to try to sell something different. Burul is and was a remarkable example of independence for her children. All six of her children are grown up and have been providing for themselves for a long time. However, Burul prefers to have her own business. Her monthly income is about ten thousand som. Aynash is forty-six. She has four children. Aynash and her husband work together at home. They raise sheep and sell milk. Aynash has decided ask for a loan to buy a milk cow.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and raise a horse and sheep

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en:
Chhuon L., 30 years old, lives with her family in the province of Kampong Chhnang in Cambodia. Her husband owns a car which he uses as a taxi. For over two years she has been working in the rice trade, buying rice directly from farmers and reselling it to earn a profit. Chhuon believes her business is doing well because she is acquiring more regular customers. She currently earns an average of $5 per day.

Chhuon's business is the main source of stable income for her family. In order to continue growing her business, Chhuon is asking for a loan to buy additional rice for future sales.

loans.use: To buy additional rice for future sales.

loans.name: Said Abrahim

texts.en:
This is S. AbR. son of S. A. R.. He lives in district 3 of Jalalabad city. He is 35 years old, married, and the father of four children: two sons and two daughters.

S. AbR. has a cotton-selling and cotton-gin (a machine that separates cotton fibers from the seeds) shop and through its income he supports his family.

S. AbR.’s income is low and he has a lot of business problems. When he was informed about the loan process that is supporting the people, he came to AFS and requested a loan of 50,000 Afghani. He will use the loan to buy cotton and to expand his business capacity.

S. AbR. hopes that, after taking the loan, it will increase his business income and he will solve his business problems, because he is a hardworking man.

S. AbR. would like to thank both Ariana Financial Services (AFS) and Kiva lenders who support people around the world through their effective loan process.

loans.use: To buy cotton

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.en:
Rogelia L. is from the village of Zone 7, Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 43 years old. Rogelia is married and has 10 school-aged children. To make a living, Rogelia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Rogelia has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Rogelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rogelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rogelia is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Rogelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni W. is currently in the business of selling sugar, milk powder,salt, etc. in a shop, and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and salt for sale. Poni is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a wildlife officer. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of sugar and salt for sale.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn N. is from the village of Zone 4, Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 28 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product range.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Allah Kan Dèmè Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de cinq  femmes  toutes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames élargies, les membres de groupe Allah Kan Dèmè ont en moyenne 44 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent dans le quartier Bamanan de Sakoïba (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, de voisinage  et exercent comme activités génératrices de revenus le commerce d’articles divers.
Après cinq  prêts de groupe tous remboursés sans aucune difficulté, elles sont à leur 6ème  prêt solidaire.
Ce nouveau prêt servira à acheter, 30 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe, 27 sacs de charbon de bois,  3 sacs de graines d’arachide, une dizaine de petits seaux en plastiques pour y mettre de la pâte d’arachide. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en bois de chauffe et  charbon de bois sur place, fournis par les exploitants de Zenguela, Soignébougou, Ouassila, Siradoba, et Bougounina ; en graines d’arachide à Konodimini et  au grand marché de Ségou (lors des foires hebdomadaires). 
Les ventes se font à Ségou généralement, de façon fixe, les jours de foire de la ville de Ségou, en ambulant  les jours ordinaires, en détail, au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 23.500 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire certains besoins familiaux,  rembourser les intérêts de prêt et participer aux évènements sociaux
Leur ambition est d’épargner pour acheter des petits ruminants (moutons, chèvres) et quelques bœufs, pour  préparer petit à petit leur avenir et celui  de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
Composed of five married women living mostly in extended polygamous families, the members of the group Allah Kan Dèmè average 44 years of age and 6 children each. They live in the Bamanan district of Sakoïba (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, and community, and they have revenue-generating businesses involving a variety of goods. After five group loans, all repaid without difficulty, they are on their sixth solidarity loan. This new loan will be used to buy 30 cart-loads of firewood, 27 sacks of charcoal, 3 sacks of peanuts, and a dozen plastic buckets in which to put peanut butter. Supplies of firewood and charcoal are gotten locally, furnished by producers from Zenguela, Soignébougou, Ouassila, Siradoba, and Bougounina. Supplies of peanuts are gotten at the big market of Ségou (at the weekly fairs). Sales are made at the retail level in cash or on credit to customers composed of women and men generally in Ségou from a fixed spot at the weekly fairs in Ségou City. On ordinary days, sales are made from place to place. The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 23,000 francs CFA that will be used to meet certain family needs, to repay the loan interest, and to assist at societal events. Their ambition is to save money to buy small ruminants (sheep, goats) and a few head of cattle in order to make a future, little by little, for themselves and for their children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods

loans.name: Keep Project Of Central Group

texts.en: Suzan N. 26, is the leader of her lending group in Bunamwaya. She is a very self-motivated and hard working lady. She has a cosmetics business that she has been running for two years. She is married with 2 children aged 6 years and 2 and a half years, and she also takes care of 3 dependants. From her business, Suzan is able to make a profit each week and she attributes this to the good customer care she delivers. Her dream is to develop her cosmetics shop further, as well as continue being a good citizen in her community. Suzan is seeking her second loan from her lending group and she hopes to use it to increase the stock in her business for more profits.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics for increased stock and sales.

loans.name: Tumurhuyag

texts.en:
Tumurhuyag T. is 41 years old and lives with her husband, son, and daughter in Zavhan province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her husband is a photographer and both of her children attend a local secondary school. T. and her husband operate a small photography studio in their town. They offer both photography and photo printing services to their customers and run their business out of a small rented room. T. and her husband have operated their business now for many years and are very hardworking. For the future, they hope to build on their experience and expand their business. Their dream is to one day have a larger, more comfortable photo studio. T. is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to purchase a scanner and some materials used in photo processing.

About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

loans.use: To purchase a scanner and some materials used in photo processing.

loans.name: Safiatou

texts.fr: S. Safiatou est née en 1974 et réside au quartier Gbégamey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis huit ans. C'est une divorcée ayant à sa charge quatre enfants, dont deux sont ses enfants et sont tous scolarisés. Safiatou vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Safiatou n'a jamais été à l'école. C'est depuis 10 ans que Safiatou mène comme activité, la vente de bouillie (fait avec l'amidon de maïs) accompagnée de beignets (fait avec la farine de blé). Safiatou mène cette activité de façon ambulante et s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Safiatou a déjà obtenu de ALIDé, deux crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Safiatou désire agrandir davantage son activité et satisfaire plus sa clientèle, afin qu'elle puisse s'élargir. C'est pourquoi, Safiatou sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
S. Safiatou was born in 1974 and has been residing in the Gbégamey district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for eight years. She is divorced and has four children to support. Two of them are hers, and all of them are in school. She lives by herself with her children and is the sole supporter of the family. Safiatou has never been to school. For ten years, she has been running a business selling porridge (made with corn starch) served with beignets (made with wheat flour). It’s a moveable operaton. She stocks up at Dantokpa, the international marketplace of Benin. She has had two ALIDé loans before which she has repaid. She wishes to expand her business further and to satisfy her customers more, in order to expand. This is why she’s requesting another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn, wheat flour, and packets of sugar

loans.name: Angaa

texts.en:
Angaa H. is 63 years old and lives with her two daughters in Uvs province in western Mongolia. She and her children live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. She operates a meat and milk trading business in her town. She also sells coal during the winter months to supplement her income. H. started her business in 2000 and has built a stable operation over the years. She works very hard at her business and has a built a very reliable customer base. Her earnings have allowed her to improve her family's quality of life and provide for her daughters' tuition fees. 

H. hopes to continue to grow her business in the future and continue to provide for her family. She says, "My wish is to educate my children and help them to lead good lives." She is requesting a 700,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of meat and milk in order to increase her business sales.

About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of meat and milk in order to increase her business sales.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth B. is a 43 year old entrepreneur from Caloocan City. She lives with her husband and their six children: one is in college, two in high school, and the rest are in grade school.
 
For six years now, Lilibeth has been a successful dealer of eggs, cooking oil, and sugar to stores and stalls in their community market. Her business is brisk and has been growing continuously. Lilibeth earns more than P40,000.00 a month.

Lilibeth has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative since 2007. The loans provided by the cooperative help her pursue her business. She is now on her seventh loan cycle as she applies for a new loan with the amount of P19,000.00, which she will use as additional capital.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar and trays of eggs.

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.en:
Dilshod A. is 28 years old, married and has a little daughter. His wife stays at home, but is currently training to be a hairdresser. She wants to open a salon so that she can supplement her husband’s income. Dilshod sells hay for animals at his house and at the market. He buys them  wholesale from local farmers. Having worked in this business for 10 years already, he is a well-known seller of hay in his village and has many clients who buy hay from his house. The price he charges for hay is based on the quantity that his customer buys. Dilshod also offers a discount to his frequent buyers who come to him often. With a loan from IMON International, Dilshod plans to increase his stock in order to fully meet the demand of his growing customers. He says that the demand is there and his problem is being able to supply enough hay. The well being of this young family is in your hands.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, such as: Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Chaka

texts.fr:
Agé de  37 ans, Monsieur Chaka  S. est marié à deux épouses, père de 5 enfants et vit chez lui-même avec sa famille dans le quartier Darsalam I de la préfecture de Koutiala  ( Région de Sikasso).  
Dû  à des problèmes de famille, il n’a pas pu continuer  les études,  raisons pour laquelle il s’est intéressé aux activités  génératrices de revenus, notamment à l’achat vente des motos d’occasion et des pièces de rechanges. Après 15 ans d’apprentissage  auprès de son grand frère, il maîtrise bien  cette activité qui lui est très rentable et  lui procure assez de revenus. Il est très sollicité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes dans le mois.  
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle et l’élargissement de son activité,  Monsieur Chaka a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à  son premier  prêt  individuel.  
Ce prêt servira à acquérir, 1 moto Djakarta occasion  et quelques pièces de rechange pour la vente. 
Il s’approvisionne auprès  des grossistes de motos  au grand marché de Koutiala et effectue sa vente dans la ville  de Koutiala à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant ou à crédit.  
Avec l’élargissement de son activité, Monsieur Chaka compte réaliser un  bénéfice de 100 000 FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts, prendre en charge les besoins de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité. 
Il envisage rembourser ce prêt correctement pour qu’il puisse bénéficier d’un autre dans le but d’élargir davantage son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Chaka S., aged 37, has two wives and is the father of five children. He lives in his own place with his family in the Darsalam I district of Koutiala prefecture (Region of Sikasso). Due to family problems, he couldn’t continue in school, and so he got interested in revenue-generating work, notably buying and selling used motorbikes and replacement parts. After fifteen years of apprenticeship with his elder brother, he has a good command of this business, which is very profitable for him and which brings in a fair amount of income. He is very much in demand and receives many orders in a month. To satisfy his customers appropriately and to expand his business, Mr. Chaka turned toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his first individual loan. This loan will serve to acquire a second-hand Djakarta motorbike and a few replacement parts to sell. He supplies himself from motorbike wholesalers at the big market of Koutiala. And he makes sales in cash or on credit to customers composed of women and men in Koutiala City. With a bigger business, he plans on realizing a profit of 100,000 francs CFA per month, which he will use to cover the loan interest and to care for his family, and he will invest the rest in his business. He anticipates repaying the loan properly, so that he may obtain another with the goal of enlarging his business still.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a used Djakarta motorbike and replacement parts

loans.name: Shar

texts.en:
Shar T. is 49 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife works as a technician at the local weather forecasting center, his oldest son operates his own cellphone trading business, and his youngest is a college student. T. operates a mobile grocery and ger wooden parts trading business in his town. 

He works hard to make his business successful, despite having a physical disability which makes operating a mobile business difficult at times. T. went into business in 2000. In 2003, he changed his business and started making felt handicrafts. However, he went back to selling groceries in 2005 after having little success. Since then he has steadily grown his grocery business and currently enjoys a stable operation. 

T. is very hardworking and hopes his future success will enable him to continue to improve his family's quality of life. He hopes to soon rent a stall at a new trading center in his town. He hopes this will be a good location and will allow him to expand his customer base. He says, "Because of my disability I would like to have one selling location for my business." T. is requesting a 363,000 tugrug loan to purchase grocery products for his business and cellphone parts for his son's business.

About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products for his business and cellphone parts for son's business.

loans.name: Chuluun

texts.en:
Chuluun M. is 40 years old and lives with his wife, five daughters and son in Uvs province in western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His oldest five children, all daughters, attend a local secondary school and his youngest son will soon start kindergarten. M. operates a coal and firewood trading business in his town. In Mongolia, coal and firewood are two common fuel sources used to heat homes and gers. His business is especially profitable during the frigid Mongolian winter months. M. also grows vegetables in the spring and summer months and plans to begin selling them after next years harvest to supplement his income. He is a very hardworking businessman and says, "I am working hard to better my family and give my children every opportunity to live happy lives." He is requesting a 250,000 tugrug (~175 USD) loan to purchase coal for his business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase coal for his business

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en:
B. Gulsara is 39 years old, married and has two school-aged children. Gulsara runs a café where she cooks patties and other national dishes. Her café is located in the central local market, which brings Gulsara many customers, the majority of which are making purchases in the market. The business has generated a stable incomes for the past seven years. Gulsara's husband is earning money in Russia and her café business is her main source of income.

Now Gulsara is planning to purchase foodstuffs such as flour, potatoes, and meat required for cooking patties. With this purpose in mind, she is requesting 5000 TJS. Gulsara has previously received several loans from Kiva partner IMON International, and has proved herself a reliable client. Today, she thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase ingredients, such as potatoes and meat, for cooking patties

loans.name: Tsegmid

texts.en:
Tsegmid T. is 22 years old and lives with her mother and two-year-old daughter in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. She lives with her family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. With her mother's help, she operates a grocery and firewood business at a small shop in her town.

T. started her business in 2006 with capital of 200,000 MNT. She has made much progress in her first three years of operation and has built a stable business. Her earnings have enabled her to provide for her mother and daughter and improve their quality of life. Today, her working capital exceeds 500,000 MNT. T. hopes to continue to grow her business in the future and provide her daughter with a good life. She is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to purchase grocery products and coal to sell.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products and coal to sell

loans.name: Bahri

texts.en:
G. Bahri is a 43-year-old loving mother of two children. Her husband is an electrician. For more than nine years Bahri has been selling fish in the city's central fish market. When she started out she turned over only a small amount of money. With time her business has expanded, and today it is quite a stable business. Bahri is requesting 5000 TJS to purchase fish at wholesale prices in order to have stock for selling during the winter. Bahri has previously received loans from Kiva partner IMON International, and has shown herself to be a reliable client. She would to thank everyone for their support.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fish wholesale

loans.name: Kyakuwa Group Of Kayunga

texts.en:
M. Grace is married with four children aged 5, 14, 16 and 18 years old. She also takes care of three dependents, all of whom are in secondary or primary school. Grace is a friendly lady who has run a retail shop in Kangulumira trading centre for 13 years. She sells general merchandise and says that, so far, she has faced no major challenges in her business. Being friendly has attracted more people to her business hence she has made more sales. She is able to make 70,000 UGX profit a week.

In the future, Grace would like to sell her merchandise wholesale in order to make more profit, educate her children, and be healthy. Grace is requesting a loan to add more stock to her shop and boost her business.

loans.use: To add more stock to her shop

loans.name: Zinhora

texts.en:
K. Zinhora is 37 years old, married and has three children. The difficult circumstances and hardships of her life made her recognize the value of work from a very young age. 

For about 11 years, Zinhora has been purchasing young sheep in the local market, fattening them, and then selling them at local markets. Zinhora is a very hardworking woman and her diligence is incredible. She works with strength worthy of immense admiration. She has always looked for a way to be an important protagonist by providing extra income for her family. Thanks to her business she is able to support her children's education. Zinhora wants to continue educating them because she hopes that they will reach the goals she laid out for herself. 

For this purpose, she is requesting a loan of $1100 USD to buy small sheep in order to expand her business. Let’s support this brave woman who has a lot of courage and strength to live. Your generosity can change lives.

loans.use: To purchase small sheep

loans.name: Murodsho

texts.ru: Аланазаров Муродшо проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 40 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Сын находится в России на заработках. Сам Муродшо болеее 14 лет занимается животноводством, он откармливает и продает скот. Кредит просит для покупки скота.
texts.en:
Murodsho A. lives in Rumy. He is forty years old. He is married and has two children. His son is in Russia working. Murodsho has been working in animal husbandry for more than fourteen years. He fattens and sells cattle. He is asking for a loan to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr: M. D. Madeleine est née en 1971 et est mariée à KPONON Cosme, un aide soignant. Madeleine vit depuis treize ans au quartier Gbégamey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Madeleine a quatre enfants en charge, dont deux sont ses propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Madeleine vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Madeleine a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire, et depuis huit ans, elle vend des fruits (orange, banane, mangue, etc.) et également du maïs grillé dans son quartier. Madeleine fait ses achats à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà obtenu deux crédits de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Pour augmenter le volume de ses produits et faire face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Madeleine sollicite un autre crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Madeleine M. D. was born in 1971 and she is married to Cosme KPONON, a nurse’s aide. For thirteen years, Madeleine has been living in the neighborhood of Gbégamey in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.

Madeleine supports four children; two of them are her own children. All the children attend school. Madeleine lives alone with her children and she, alone, provides for the family’s expenses. Madeleine stopped attending school in middle school. For the last eight years, she has been selling fruits (oranges, bananas, mangoes etc…) and also grilled corn in her neighborhood. Madeleine makes her purchases in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.

She is a long time client of ALIDé who has already received two loans from ALIDé. Those have been fully repaid. To increase the volume of her produces and to meet the ever-increasing demand of her customers, Madeleine is requesting another loan from ALIDé.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of baskets of oranges, mangoes, and bananas.

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en:
M. Munavvar is a bread maker. She has her own bakery in her house. With experience has come success in this business. She’s been able to succeed by diversifying her products. Munavvar makes white bread, sweet bread, buns and pastries. Munavvar’s immediate need is to acquire basic ingredients to continue baking bread. This is why she’s looking for support from IMON International, to obtain credit that will allow her to buy the ingredients she needs and continue her bakery business at home. With your support, you can improve the quality of life for Munavvar and her family and help her business grow and prosper.

loans.use: To purchase flour at wholesale for baking the national bread “lepeshka”.

loans.name: Uktamjon

texts.en:
M. Uktamjon is 42 years old. He is married and has two children. His wife is a housekeeper. Uktamjon processes and sells dried apricots in the central local market. He is experienced in the business of making the dried apricots. As a rule, he purchases dried apricots in the market and processes them himself. Because he buys dried apricot wholesale, his prices are lower than regular market prices. He offers a wide assortment of goods for clients of different means. All this allows Uktamjon to make his business quite successful and it brings a stable income for the family. Today Uktamjon requests $800 USD. He is going to spend the loan to purchase dried apricots to process to sell. He would like to increase his income and give his children a good education. Uktamjon expresses his gratitude for everyone supporting him.

loans.use: To buy more apricots to process and sell

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
This is Zenaida M. from Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.  She is a mother to four children. All but one of her children study in different school levels.  Her husband Stephen is a freelance videographer/photographer.

Zenaida manages a photo/video coverage studio.  She negotiates with clients while her husband does the actual video/photo coverage.  They cover different functions like weddings, birthdays, graduation ceremonies and other family oriented activities.  Zenaida’s net monthly income from the studio is P10,000.00.  She is happy that her profits can answer the technical needs of their business although she laments that some clients fail to redeem their photos from the studio and so are just stocked up in their archives, which translates to business losses.

Zenaida currently needs a loan of P30,000.00 to purchase some of their studio’s technical requirements like digital flash for the cameras and batteries.  This will be her 14th loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy technical equipment for photography (digital flash, batteries,etc.)

loans.name: Gulom

texts.ru: Джуманазаров Гулом проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 30 лет. Разведен, имеет 2 детей. Брат с которым он живет находится в России на заработках. Сам Гулом более 10 лет занимается откармливанием и продажей скота. Кредит просит для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Gulom J. lives in Rumy. He is thirty years old. He is divorced and has two children. He brother, with whom he lives, is working in Russia. Gulom has been working fattening and selling cattle for more than ten years. He is asking for a loan to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Suraiyo

texts.en:
N. Suraiyo is a 36-year-old mother whose husband has no fixed income. So, to cover day-to-day necessities, she processes and sells dried apricots with the help of her elder son. She uses all the money she makes to care for her three children and provide for their education. Suraiyo has 15 years of experience processing and selling dried apricots. She is very polite and considerate, and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her. Because her business is doing so well, she is increasing her net worth month by month. Today Suraiyo requests $1200 USD to purchase more dried apricots to process and increase her range of goods. Suraiyo and her son express their gratitude for everyone supporting them and they promise to repay their loan in a timely manner.
